analysis.title: Living Beer
analysis.author: Mark J Burkholder
analysis.logline: Three friends running a small craft brewery face a crisis when their anticipated beer release suffers a bottling disaster, forcing them to choose between their dreams and practical realities.
analysis.tone: Warm, authentic comedy with dramatic undercurrents

concept.justification: The concept of a small craft brewery startup facing a crisis is relatable and has merit, but lacks a truly distinctive hook that would make it immediately compelling beyond the niche craft beer audience.

structure.justification: The script has a functional three-act structure but feels somewhat compressed at 39 pages, with limited space to fully develop character arcs and plot complications. The crisis comes relatively late with a somewhat rushed resolution.

protagonist.justification: Ben is a functional protagonist with clear goals around making his brewery successful, but his character arc (considering leaving for a corporate job vs. staying with his passion) isn't fully developed or resolved with sufficient clarity.

supporting_cast.justification: Joe, Gus, and Shana are reasonably well-differentiated with distinct personalities, skillsets and perspectives that complement each other well. They have individual voices and bring different energies to scenes.

dialogue.justification: The dialogue contains effective craft beer jargon that creates authenticity and humor. Characters have distinct voices, particularly Shana whose no-nonsense attitude contrasts well with the guys' beer geek enthusiasm.

genre_execution.justification: As a workplace comedy-drama, it hits expected beats but doesn't fully explore the emotional stakes or maximize comedic potential. The script knows its world but plays it somewhat safe without delivering exceptional comedy set pieces or deeply emotional moments.

originality.justification: The craft beer setting provides a specific backdrop, but the storyline of small business owners facing a crisis follows familiar patterns. The script competently portrays its world without bringing a highly distinctive perspective.

major_weaknesses: Length insufficient to fully develop premise
Protagonist's final choice lacks definitive resolution

target_audience.note: Identifiable craft beer and entrepreneurship-minded audience

high_concept.note: Takes several sentences to explain the premise

cast_attachability.note: Lead roles offer some meat but not standout vehicles

marketing_hook.note: Craft beer crisis doesn't provide strong visual marketing

budget_return_ratio.note: Low budget potential with modest returns

comparable_success.note: Recent comparable workplace comedies have performed modestly

structure_analysis.act_breaks: Act 1 ends when the bottling problem is discovered, Act 2 climax is Ben's decision to reveal the problem to customers
structure_analysis.pacing: medium, with a somewhat compressed third act

characters.protagonist: Ben, a brewery owner torn between craft beer passion and business practicalities with clear goal of making brewery successful
characters.antagonist: No clear antagonist; conflict comes from bottling crisis and internal tensions
supporting: Joe: the passionate brewmaster focused on quality
Gus: marketing-savvy friend with people skills
Shana: no-nonsense bar manager bringing practical experience
Steve Martinez: represents corporate beer world and temptation

standout_scenes.scene: The beer tasting scene when the three friends first try their creation
standout_scenes.why: Authentic enthusiasm and technical jargon establishes character dynamics and the central importance of the beer

standout_scenes.scene: Shana's interview where she completely flips the script on the guys
standout_scenes.why: Injects energy, humor and a fresh perspective while demonstrating actual bar knowledge

standout_scenes.scene: Ben's announcement of the bottling problem and Becca's spontaneous solution
standout_scenes.why: Pays off the community aspect of craft beer culture in an authentic way

comparable_films.title: Drinking Buddies
comparable_films.similarity: Craft beer setting, relationship dynamics, authentic portrayal of the industry

comparable_films.title: Chef
comparable_films.similarity: Passionate craftsperson story, small business focus, friendship dynamics

budget_tier.justification: Limited locations (primarily brewery), modest cast size, no special effects needed

strengths: Authentic portrayal of craft beer culture with accurate terminology and processes
Strong character dynamics between the three friends and Shana
Effective use of dialogue to establish character and create humor
Clear understanding of the tension between craft and commerce
weaknesses: At 39 pages, insufficient length to fully develop premise for feature or typical pilot
Ben's potential decision to leave for corporate job isn't sufficiently developed or resolved
Bottling crisis feels somewhat contrived and comes late in the script
Limited character development beyond their relationship to the brewery
development_notes: Expand to either full feature length (90+ pages) or standard pilot length (55-60 pages)
Introduce the bottling problem earlier to drive more of the narrative
Deepen Ben's character arc with clearer resolution of his temptation to go corporate
Further develop Joe and Gus beyond their brewery roles to enrich potential series characters
Strengthen the distinctive visual style and comedic set pieces
assessment.marketability: medium-low - while craft beer has a dedicated following, the premise lacks strong high-concept elements that would make it immediately marketable beyond this niche
assessment.recommendation_rationale: With a weighted score of 5.95, no critical failures, and a CVS of 9, this script meets the baseline for CONSIDER. While it doesn't reach RECOMMEND thresholds due to its concept score of 6, short length, and lack of exceptional standout elements, the authentic world-building and character dynamics show promise.

analysis.verdict_statement: This screenplay shows genuine authenticity in its depiction of craft beer culture and establishes engaging character dynamics, but requires development attention to expand its length, deepen character arcs, and strengthen its dramatic structure. With proper expansion to either feature or full pilot length and a more defined resolution for Ben's character arc, this project could achieve RECOMMEND status.
